content.description: Alcohol-related disorders encompass a spectrum including Alcohol Use Disorder (AUD), Alcohol Intoxication, and Alcohol Withdrawal. Alcohol is a CNS depressant with widespread social use but significant potential for misuse, dependence, and medical complications.

mechanisms: Potentiation of GABA-A receptor activity leading to CNS depression and anxiolysis.
Inhibition of NMDA glutamate receptors contributing to cognitive/motor impairment.
Mesolimbic dopamine release reinforcing reward and addictive behaviors.
Chronic use leads to neuroadaptation with downregulation of GABA activity and upregulation of glutamate, underlying withdrawal symptoms.

diagnostic_criteria.use_disorder: A problematic pattern of alcohol use leading to clinically significant impairment/distress, manifested by ≥2 criteria within a 12-month period (e.g., tolerance, withdrawal, craving, loss of control, continued use despite harm).
diagnostic_criteria.intoxication: Recent ingestion of alcohol with clinically significant maladaptive behavior or psychological changes (e.g., inappropriate sexual/aggressive behavior, mood lability, impaired judgment) plus ≥1: slurred speech, incoordination, unsteady gait, nystagmus, impaired attention/memory, stupor/coma. Not due to another condition.
diagnostic_criteria.withdrawal: Cessation/reduction after heavy prolonged use, with ≥2 within hours–days: autonomic hyperactivity, hand tremor, insomnia, nausea/vomiting, hallucinations, psychomotor agitation, anxiety, seizures. Not due to another condition.

content.prevalence: AUD affects ~5–6% of U.S. adults annually; prevalence higher among men and younger adults; global burden varies widely.
content.age_of_onset: Commonly begins in late adolescence or early adulthood; severe AUD may develop after years of heavy use.
content.prognosis: With treatment and sustained abstinence, prognosis is favorable; without treatment, course is often chronic-relapsing with risk of cirrhosis, cardiomyopathy, neuropathy, Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome, and death.

history: Detailed use pattern (quantity, frequency, duration, last drink)
physical_exam: Vitals (BP, HR, temp) for autonomic hyperactivity
Neuro exam for tremor, ataxia, nystagmus

use_disorder: Craving and inability to cut down

withdrawal.mild: Tremor, anxiety, insomnia without autonomic instability

environmental: Peer use, cultural norms favoring drinking

impact_on_life.medical: Liver disease, pancreatitis, neuropathy, cognitive decline.
impact_on_life.legal: DUI, arrests related to intoxicated behavior.

medications: Naltrexone (oral or XR) to reduce craving
Benzodiazepines (lorazepam, diazepam, chlordiazepoxide) for acute withdrawal management
Adjuncts: gabapentin, carbamazepine for mild/moderate withdrawal
care_coordination: Linkage to addiction specialists, inpatient detox if high risk for severe withdrawal

treatment_goals: Achieve and maintain abstinence or harm reduction
missed_diagnosis_factors: Attributing symptoms to depression/anxiety without assessing alcohol use
Underestimating quantity/frequency due to patient minimization
Failure to recognize atypical withdrawal presentations in older adults
overdiagnosis_factors: Misattributing isolated binge episodes as AUD without persistent pattern
Confusing alcohol odor with intoxication without functional impairment

adolescents: Impact on brain development and academic performance
older_adults: Heightened sensitivity due to slower metabolism
Interaction with medications, increased fall risk

real_life_examples: A 25-year-old with daily heavy drinking develops tremors and anxiety within 8 hours of last drink; admitted for monitored detox with benzodiazepines and thiamine.
A 50-year-old with escalating alcohol use despite liver enzyme elevation starts naltrexone and CBT, achieving 6 months of sobriety.
content.when_to_seek_help: Seek immediate care for seizures, confusion, severe withdrawal symptoms, or thoughts of self-harm. Prompt evaluation for inability to control drinking or withdrawal within hours of cessation.

positive_factors: Engagement in treatment and peer support
challenging_factors: Unstable housing or ongoing high-risk environment
